Governor Rauner: s FY16 budget proposal included freezing grant funding for autism and homeless prevention programs at DHS and eliminating the After School Matters program at the Illinois State Board of Education.
In April 2015: Governor Rauner announced his plan to freeze funding for autism and homeless prevention, which resulted in cuts to autism programs, assistance for the homeless, and Teen REACH (an after-school program for high-risk youth).
The cuts to these programs were referred: Good Friday Massacre" by Democrats and were later restored when higher-than-expected tax revenue was reported.
The expert: s analysis found that Governor Rauner did call for the elimination or reduction of funding for afterschool programs for at-risk youth, homeless prevention services, and programs that help autistic children in multiple instances from 2015 to 2017.
